subject: RE: [junit] Private method throws an exception
msgSnippet: In my case, I know exactly what the problem is.  The private method relies on external resources that are not available during unit testing (i.e. Torque/DBMS).

In my case, I know exactly what the problem is.  The private method relies =
on external resources that are not available during unit testing (i.e. Torq=
ue/DBMS).

 

My question was not how to find an unknown failure, but how t=
o eliminate a known failure caused by an external dependency buried inside =
a private method.

 

For public/protected method dependencies, I extend th=
e class under test and override and simplify those methods.  Unfortunately,=
 this doesn=E2=80=99t work for private methods.

 

I think the answer is t=
o refactor the private method to support some form of dependency injection =
so I can insert mock objects that eliminate the exception.

 

My question =
was whether they may be a better/more efficient approach?

 

Thanks again =
for your help.

-Mitch

 

  _____  

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:j=
unit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Elliotte Harold
Sent: Monday, October 31=
, 2005 5:11 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Private metho=
d throws an exception

 

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> If you have a failing=
 test, but you aren't sure why it fails, and you 
> suspect the problem is =
in a private method, what do you generally do?

If I have a failing test th=
at fails because an exception is thrown out 
of a private method, I debug i=
t. First off I eyeball the code both in 
the private method and the public =
method being tested. Most of the time 
the reason for the failure is obviou=
s. If it's not, I'll generally set a 
breakpoint or two and step through th=
e code in the debugger and watch 
what actually happens. This is a lot more=
 productive than guessing at 
what the problem might be. If I could guess r=
ight, then I wouldn't need 
to step through it.

It used to be common in qu=
ality code to do a code review by stepping 
through the entire program in a=
 debugger. This tended to reveal a lot of 
surprises about how the code was=
 really working. This technique has 
fallen out of favor as applications gr=
ew larger. It's really impractical 
today. However, when something is going=
 wrong in a known piece of code 
nothing beats single stepping through it i=
n a debugger. This almost 
always points me to the exact statement where wh=
at I think the code is 
doing diverges from what the code is actually doing=
.

This requires that the bug is consistently reproducible and I have a 
te=
st that reproduces it. However, once I've got that I'm good to go. 
Writing=
 hypothetical tests for what I think the bug might be only works 
if the bu=
g is so obvious that I can eyeball it in the first place. The 
tricky bugs =
are the ones where everything looks like it should work and 
I can't see wh=
y it doesn't. That's when I need to isolate the problem 
more closely than =
a test method can. I need to find out which statement 
is failing, not whic=
h method is failing. I already know the answer to 
the latter question.

If=
 the bug proves to be deep inside another piece of code, then I might 
late=
r add a second test that aims more closely at the bug. However, 
that's onl=
y done after I've identified the bug, and often I don't even 
bother to do =
that. After all, there's already at least one test for the 
issue.

--
